title: Ticket #7247: Docker jobs can't be gracefully terminated
description: When HTCondor kills Docker jobs, unlike other vanilla universe jobs, it always uses a hardkill. This is problematic for people (SWAMP) whose Docker jobs need time to shut down cleanly in order to be useful.
remarks:
2019-Sep-12 16:43:29 by tannenba:
So with this patch, will the following job work as expected?

If my quoting foo is still good :), the below job will hang out until it gets a SIGTERM, at which point it will say so to stdout, and then exit 10 seconds later. 

universe = docker
docker_image = centos
executable = /bin/bash
arguments = -c '(trap "(printf \"Got TERM at \"; date; sleep 10)" SIGTERM; trap "(echo -n \"EXITING at \"; date)" EXIT; sleep 50000)'
want_graceful_removal = true

# Upon removing this job, test1.out should have both 'Got TERM at' and 'Exiting at'
output = test1.out
job_max_vacate_time = 20
queue

# Upon removing this job, test2.out should only have 'Got TERM at' because
# it should be hard-killed before it can print it exits.
output = test2.out
job_max_vacate_time = 5
queue

2019-Sep-12 23:04:59 by tlmiller:
What I (manually) tested was basically exactly the same as your question, and it does work (where docker/out shows the SIGTERM being received and the job either proceeding to finish or stopping after 10 seconds, depending on whether job_max_vacate_time was set. 

docker.submit
output                  = docker/out
error                   = docker/error
log                     = docker/log

docker_image            = debian
executable              = docker.sh
arguments               = 60
universe                = docker
should_transfer_files   = YES

stream_output           = TRUE
stream_error            = TRUE

# Tested with and without this line.
job_max_vacate_time     = 10

queue 1


docker.sh
#!/bin/bash

trap handleTerm SIGTERM

function handleTerm {
    echo "Caught SIGTERM, ignoring..."
}

i=0
while [ $i -lt $1 ]; do echo $i; i=$((i+1)); sleep 1; done
exit 0
